Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Electricity From Biomimetic Grass
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase I project will develop the feasibility of using piezoelectric transducers to create an artificial plant, embodied as tall bunchgrass, that will harvest and store energy from wind. This device will have aesthetic appeal and provide a nonpolluting supplement to energy produced by wind turbines and combustion of fossil fuels. Rugged plastic leaves containing piezoelectric Kynar inserts will generate pulses of electricity when flexed by wind. Electrical currents will be full-wave rectified by diode bridges at the base of each leaf and routed in parallel to a smart battery charger.

The broader/commercial impact of the project will be to produce energy from wind without the environmental concerns related to wind turbines. Currently, wind energy harvesting is accomplished with wind turbines that drive large electromagnetic generators. Turbines are mounted atop high towers often in rural districts in order to avoid turbulent airflow typical of populated areas, and also to meet threshold wind speed requirements. As wind-farms have spread, environmental concerns have been raised about their effects on wildlife, local wind patterns, and the health of nearby residents. This project will develop a new and transformational technology that exploits engineering solutions evolved by plants over the years that they have been interacting with wind.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ecological and economic concerns require development of renewable energy sources of minimal environmental impact. Towards this goal, wind energy harvesting is on the rise, but just ½ per cent of energy consumed by the U.S. in 2008 came from wind farms. In this project we tested the feasibility of a completely different mechanism for converting wind energy to electricity than used by wind turbines. The idea is to tap the motional (kinetic) energy of artificial plants moving in the wind. A key component is special “piezoelectric” materials that generate electrical charge when flexed. These materials are used widely for sensor technology, and some are pliable enough to be inserted into the leaves or stems of artificial plants without severely altering motional properties.

 

In principle, a faux tree or tall grass plant with “piezoelectric” leaves might provide an aesthetically agreeable means to generate and store power sufficient to energize small household appliances, independent of the power grid. Structural elements of the tree presumably could be built from recycled plastic bottles. Unlike wind turbines, which must be placed atop 30 – 100 ft. towers to evade turbulence and slower airflow at lower heights, leaves flutter in turbulent airstreams at or below the ~ 7 mph threshold of conventional turbines. The critical question is just how much electrical energy could one produce with piezoelectric plants.

 

To contribute meaningfully, we reasoned that each bio-inspired tree or plant must generate >10 W of electrical power. Of the several bio-inspired devices we built, none were capable of this wattage. For example, plastic cottonwood leaves oscillated at natural flutter frequencies (~ 2-4 Hz) in wind streams of 10-12 miles per hour, yet each leaf generated only one ten millionth the targeted power. It would be impractical to build and install artificial trees meeting the10 watt benchmark.

 

Piezoelectric devices can generate substantial voltages, but they release charge reluctantly (high output impedance). Output impedance is related inversely to capacitance, so in an effort to circumvent this limitation we built stacks of long piezoelectric leaflets (high capacitance). These showed a decrease in output impedance with leaflet number or size, but power production remained orders below our target. The low frequencies and stress levels that typify wind-driven plant motions are not effective at charging up present-day piezoelectrics, nor is there yet an efficient way to transfer charge to low impedance batteries.


Last Modified: 03/27/2011
Modified by: Michael Mccloskey
